title: Part a. [0–2]
stimulusHtml:
2 points

1 point: For an arrow downward on or near antenna

1 point: For one correct justification statement

Examples: F = qv × B , the right-hand rule, − (north × down) = east, the left-hand rule for electrons
descriptions:
The student response earns none of the following points:

No points earned

1 point: For an arrow downward on or near antenna

1 point: For one correct justification statement

Examples: F = qv × B , the right-hand rule, − (north × down) = east, the left-hand rule for electrons

The student response earns one of the following points:

Earns 1 of 2 points

1 point: For an arrow downward on or near antenna

1 point: For one correct justification statement

Examples: F = qv × B , the right-hand rule, − (north × down) = east, the left-hand rule for electrons

The student response earns all of the following points:

Earns 2 of 2 points

1 point: For an arrow downward on or near antenna

1 point: For one correct justification statement

Examples: F = qv × B , the right-hand rule, − (north × down) = east, the left-hand rule for electrons

title: Part b. [0–5]
stimulusHtml:
5 points

An equilibrium is reached when the electric force due to the separation of charge in the antenna balances the magnetic force on an electron

1 point: For a correct expression for the magnetic force, showing a cross product or an angular dependence

1 point: For a correct expression for the electric force

Equating the electric and magnetic forces:

qE = qv x B

1 point: For substitution of sin 55°
1 point: For substitution of other given values

title: Part c. [0–2]
stimulusHtml:
2 points

Using the relationship between electric field and potential difference for the linear situation:

V = Ed

1 point: For substitution of the value of E from part (b)

1 point: For substitution of the correct length, 15 m

V = (0.0037 V / m)(15 m)

V = 0.0553 V

An alternate method is to do part (c) first, using principles noted in part (b), then substituting V into the relationship V = Ed to obtain E. Points equivalent to those above were awarded for this method.

title: Part d. [0–1]
stimulusHtml:
1 point

For indicating that the top of the wing is at the higher potential

Note: To earn credit, this answer must be consistent with the student's answer to part (a)
descriptions:
The student response earns none of the following points:

No point earned.

For indicating that the top of the wing is at the higher potential

Note: To earn credit, this answer must be consistent with the student's answer to part (a)

Earns 1 of 1 point.

title: Part e. [0–5]
stimulusHtml:
5 points (i. 3 points; ii. 2 points)

i. 3 points

2 points: For indicating that there must be a change in the magnetic flux through the closed loop

1 point: For specifying a correct change in the plane's orientation or the connected wire that could result in a change in flux through the closed loop.

ii. 2 points

1 point: For any indication of the position of the connected wire in the closed loop

1 point: For showing the correct direction of the resulting induced current on the diagram, based upon the conditions indicated in part (e) i.

Examples

Ex. 1: The connecting wire trails behind the antenna, over the body of the plane. The plane goes into a forward dive, increasing its angle with respect to horizontal.

Ex. 2: The connecting wire loops under the wing, directly under the antenna. The plane makes a level right turn.

Other acceptable concepts were arranging the loop so its area can be changed, or shielding a part of the circuit from the magnetic field.
